page.title: Coordination Constructions
page.introduction:
This section mainly considers basic coordination constructions where there is an overt conjunction between the conjuncts. We will deal with coordination at the sentence level and at the verb phrase, nominal phrase, prepositional or postpositional phrase and adjective phrase levels. Then, at the nominal phrase level only, we will deal with lists and appositive constructions. Finally, comparative constructions involving full sentences will be discussed. (Shorter comparatives were covered in
Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Comparatives.) More complex types of coordination constructions, such as gapping, and other possible levels of coordination will need to be dealt with later.

form.introduction: In English, the conjunctions which can be used between two conjuncts are and, or, but and and/or. In addition, there are coordination constructions which require an initial conjunction, such as either...or and neither...nor constructions. Some languages also use a word meaning with as a conjunction between nominal phrases.

form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the feature plural to the conjunctions written as a separate word meaning ‘and’, ‘and/or’ and ‘with’, and also to any other conjunctions in your language which require plural agreement when they are used to conjoin nominal phrases. Also, add the feature -conjoins_IP to any conjunction, such as ‘with’, used for conjoining nominal phrases only. Add the feature negative to the negative conjunctions meaning ‘nor’ and ‘neither’. Add the feature makeInitialConj to the conjunction words meaning ‘either’ and ‘neither’ that are used in the initial position. If the same conjunction word can also be used in the medial position, you will need to make two lexical entries, so one can maintain the category Conj.

In the lexicon, add the feature conj_prefix to the conjunctions that attach to the beginning of the second conjunct. Also add the feature conj_prefix_pl to the conjunctions that attach to the beginning of the second conjunct meaning ‘and’, ‘and/or’ and ‘with’, and also to any others which require plural agreement when they are used to conjoin nominal phrases. In addition, add the feature conj_prefix_neg to the negative conjunctions meaning ‘nor’ that attach to the beginning of the second conjunct.

In the lexicon, add the feature conj_suffix to the conjunctions that attach to the end of the first conjunct. Also add the feature conj_suffix_pl to the conjunctions that attach to the end of the first conjunct meaning ‘and’, ‘and/or’ and ‘with’, and also to any others which require plural agreement when they are used to conjoin nominal phrases. In addition, add the feature conj_suffix_neg to the negative conjunctions meaning ‘nor’ that attach to the end of the first conjunct.

In the lexicon, add the feature conj_prefix to the conjunctions that attach to the beginning of the second conjunct and the feature conj_suffix to the conjunctions that attach to the end of the first conjunct. Also add the feature conj_prefix_pl or the feature conj_suffix_pl as appropriate to the conjunctions that attach to one of the conjuncts meaning ‘and’, ‘and/or’ and ‘with’, and also to any others which require plural agreement when they are used to conjoin nominal phrases. In addition, add the feature conj_prefix_neg or the feature conj_suffix_neg as appropriate to the negative conjunctions meaning ‘nor’ that attach to one of the conjuncts.

Specific phrase structure rules for the coordination constructions with attached conjunctions in your language will need to be added after completion of the PAWS Starter Kit. For now, the rules without any conjunction are given, and they should work fairly well.

form.introduction: In general, coordination is between like categories. For sentence-level coordination, this means that two declarative sentences may be conjoined, as in 1-2, or two questions, as in 3. When the conjunction is the one meaning ‘but’, one of the conjuncts must be negative, as in 4. English examples of full sentence coordination include:

EnglishExample.exItem: John went to the office this morning but he did not return.
Either I will come to the party or I will send my sister.
When did the mail come and where is my package?
John went to the office this morning but he did not return.

form.introduction: Verb phrase coordination involves two full verb phrases that share a single subject. English examples of verb phrase coordination, with the coordinates bracketed, include:

EnglishExample.exItem: Bill [ran the race] and [won the prize].
I will [come to the party] or [send my sister].
I will not [come to the party] nor [send my sister].

form.introduction: Coordinate nominal phrases can normally occur as subjects, objects, indirect objects and objects of a preposition or postposition, just like a regular nominal phrase. English examples of nominal phrase coordination, with the coordinates bracketed, include:

EnglishExample.exItem: Bill ran in [the Boston Marathon] and [the Olympics].
[My sister] or [I] will be there.
Neither [my sister] nor [I] will be there.
I will come to [the rehearsal] but not [the dinner].
I will come to [the wedding] and/or [the reception].

form.prompt: Key examples of nominal phrase coordination in your language here (without bracktes). Include only examples with two conjucts and an overt conjunction between the conjuncts. Other types of nominal phrase coordination will be dealt with on the next page.
form.introduction: It is also normally possible to have coordinate prepositional or postpositional phrases in all the places that a regular such phrase normally occurs. English examples with prepositional phrase coordination, with the coordinates bracketed, include:

EnglishExample.exItem: Bill ran [through the forest] and [over the bridge].
I will come with you [to the rehearsal] but not [back home].
I will come either [to the wedding] or [to the reception].

form.introduction: Finally, adjectives or adjective phrases can usually be coordinated, both when they are modifying a noun, as in 16-18, and when they are acting as the predicate adjective in a copular sentence, as in 19-20. English examples of adjective phrase coordination, with the coordinates bracketed where not clear, include:

EnglishExample.exItem: The black and white dog belongs to my son.
My sister wants a [bright red] or [light blue] candle.
That looks like an [awfully painful] and [very dangerous] sore on your leg.
The sore on your leg is [awfully painful] and [very dangerous].
This material feels [very smooth] and [silky].
